properties.media:imagetext:
September 7, 1937
PERSONAL AND CONFIDENTIAL
Mr. H. M. Bixby
Pan American Airways Company
Manila, P. I.
Dear Mr. Bixby:
I have just received your memoranda written in Shanghai on
August 20 and on board the SS PRESIDENT PIERCE on August 25, giving a
very complete description of what transpired in Shanghai during the days
immediately preceding your departure.
This serves in a large measure to
answer the request made in my letter No. 195 of August 24 for a full re-
port.
There are a few holes you will notice, and which I think on fur-
ther
consideration you will want to fill up,
but it gives us a pretty
complete picture so
that we now know quite well what happened, although
it will take considerable further study to decide just what our legal
position is.
Unfortunately, you put most of this report in the form of
and confidential letter containing
a few paragraphs which
you yourself stipulated mist be "off the record".
This, of course, makes
it useless for record purposes, but I shall probably take the liberty of
rewriting a few pages as we must have most of this on our files for future
use in connection with claims,
ete.--or perhaps you would prefer to write
another report with this end definitely in view and with no confidential
material included.
It is very apparent from your reports that you took the only
action possible under the circumstances,
and of course we felt certain of
this all along.
Your description of events is most graphic, and in fact
the news reels from Shanghai have just reached New York so that we can see
or at least ingine what you went through.
It must have been indeed a
terrible experience for all concerned.
Referring to your telegram No. 126 with suggestion for trans-
ferring title to certain equipment no longer in our possession, and billing
CNAC in the amount of $110,000, I am sure you will understand that our
reply (telegram No. 112) was written primarily for record purposes.
I at
least,
and
I am sure you also, cannot have any illusions as to our Chinese
associates viewing the proposed action as highly cooperative, nor,
I fear,
can any of us entertain much
hope of a renewal of joint activities,
although of
course anything can happen.
properties.wof:name: correspondence: S.W. Morgan to Harold M. Bixby
